stem: A client is admitted to the trauma unit after a high-speed motor vehicle collision with a suspected T2 spinal cord injury. Based on the documentation in the Hemodynamic & Autonomic Stability Log, which complication is the client experiencing?

tabs.title: Physical Assessment
tabs.content: Current: Skin is pink, warm, and dry to the touch throughout. No signs of active hemorrhage noted on secondary survey. Capillary refill is 4 seconds. Client is alert but sluggish.

tabs.title: Injury Context
tabs.content: Confirmed: Complete transection of the spinal cord at the T2 level. Loss of all sympathetic innervation below the level of the injury.

rationale.correct: This is **Neurogenic Shock (a1)**. It is unique among shocks because it presents with the combination of **Hypotension AND Bradycardia** (HR 44). In other shocks, the body compensates for low pressure by increasing the heart rate (Tachycardia). However, in a T6+ spinal injury, the sympathetic 'fight or flight' signals are cut off, leaving the heart 'disconnected' and unable to speed up, while the vessels dilate (leading to **pink, warm, dry skin**).
clinicalPearls: Neurogenic Shock = Hypotension + Bradycardia + Warm Skin.
Treatment: Vasopressors (to constrict vessels) and Atropine (to increase heart rate).
Do not confuse with Hypovolemic shock (which has Cold, Pale skin and Tachycardia).

questionTrap.trap: Choosing Hypovolemic Shock (a2) because the patient was in a car crash.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Check the **Heart Rate**. If the patient is 'bleeding out' (Hypovolemic), they will be Tachycardic. If they are 'Neuro-disconnected' (Neurogenic), they will be Bradycardic. Heart rate is the differentiator.

mnemonic.title: Neuro-Normal
mnemonic.expansion: Neurogenic Shock is the only one where the skin feels 'Normal' (Pink/Warm) while the pressure is Low.
